item.title: Q. And A.: Dispute Over Kurds Threatens U.S.-Turkey Alliance
item.description: Here are five questions about the Kurds and their role in the rapidly evolving events in Syria and Turkey.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A Kurdish fighter in January 2015 in the wreckage of a building in the center of the Syrian town of Kobani on the Turkish border.

item.title: Letter From Africa: Truth, Reconciliation and Now, a Prosecution in South Africa
item.description: Four police officers will be tried in the torture and murder of an anti-apartheid courier in 1983, a triumph for the judicial process, however slow.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Taiwan Earthquake Search Uncovers Body of Last Missing Person
item.description: The discovery brings the death toll from the Feb. 6 earthquake to 117, all but two of whom perished in the collapse of a 17-story apartment complex.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Heavy machinery excavating the Wei-Guan Golden Dragon apartment complex in Tainan, Taiwan. The remains of a homeless woman, the last known victim of the Feb. 6 earthquake, were found on Thursday.

item.title: In Defense of Trump, Some Point (Wrongly) to Vatican Walls
item.description: Scholars say a basic misunderstanding of the geography and history of Vatican City is at the center of criticism that the pope is being hypocritical in his remarks about Donald Trump’s call to build a wall between the U.S. and Mexico.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.media:description: St. Peter’s Square in Vatican City in 2013.

item.title: World Briefing: Ghana: Dozens Killed in Road Accident
item.description: A head-on collision between a passenger bus and a truck killed at least 61 people in the deadliest road accident in recent memory in the country, officials and witnesses said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine: Governing Coalition Splinters
item.description: The governing coalition lost its majority in Parliament after a second faction bailed out.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Obama Going to Cuba; First Visit by U.S. President in 88 Years
item.description: The visit is part of an effort to end more than a half-century of estrangement and forge normalized relations with a Cold War adversary.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Raúl Castro of Cuba, left, with President Obama at the United Nations in New York in September.

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine: Unicef Warns of Conflict’s Toll on Children
item.description: More than 500,000 children in eastern Ukraine have been “deeply affected” by the trauma of living through the violence between government forces and insurgents that began two years ago, Unicef said.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Afghanistan: Red Cross Halts Work in Ghazni Province After Kidnappings
item.description: An armed group abducted five local staff members of the international aid organization on a road in the province, where there have been frequent kidnappings and murders on the highways.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Donald Trump Fires Back at Sharp Rebuke by Pope Francis
item.description: Mr. Trump’s attack on Francis reflected a political calculation that criticizing the pope will not hurt him with conservatives — and might even improve his standing in South Carolina.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK HEALY
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump, signing an autograph in South Carolina on Thursday. Polls suggest that the state’s primary contest is tightening.

item.title: World Briefing: India: Protests Spread After an Arrest
item.description: Students and teachers in at least 10 cities demanded the release of a student leader arrested on sedition charges and accused of being anti-Indian.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Francis Says Contraception Can Be Used to Slow Zika
item.description: The pope’s remarks stirred up divisions in the leadership of the Roman Catholic Church in South America about whether birth control should be widely allowed.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Pope Francis back in Rome after a trip to Mexico. He made his statement on birth control and Zika on his flight home.

item.title: Agreement Clears the Way for Airdrops of Humanitarian Aid in Syria
item.description: The United Nations World Food Program will start its first airdrops in Syria in coming days, using aircraft provided by a Russian contractor.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An aid convoy headed to the towns of Fouaa and Kfarya in Syria on Wednesday.

item.title: As Uganda Votes, Polling Stations Open Hours Late and a Candidate Is Arrested
item.description: Kizza Besigye, the main challenger to President Yoweri Museveni, was apprehended by the Ugandan authorities, who did not comment on the arrest.
item.dc:creator: JOSH KRON
item.media:credit: Carl De Souza/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: People lined up to vote at the Nasuti polling station east of Kampala, the Ugandan capital, on Thursday.

item.title: New West Bank Violence as Palestinian Boys Stab 2 Israelis
item.description: The latest attack, which killed an off-duty Israeli soldier, came as Israeli officials clashed over the degree of force to be used against Palestinian minors with weapons.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Israeli security forces at a supermarket in the occupied West Bank after two Palestinians stabbed two Israeli men on Thursday. One of the victims, an off-duty soldier, was killed.

item.title: European Union Struggling With How to Keep Britain in the Fold
item.description: The leaders of the 28 nations are meeting in Brussels to confront issues over Britain and the migrant crisis that challenge the longtime goal of “ever closer union.”
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, left, the European Commission president, Jean-Claude Juncker, and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany lined up for a photo during a summit meeting in Brussels on Thursday.

item.title: Volkswagen Memos Suggest Emissions Problem Was Known Earlier
item.description: Documents suggesting VW executives knew of elevated diesel emissions in early 2014 could create problems with regulators, car owners and stockholders.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING
item.media:description: Martin Winterkorn, Volkswagen’s former chief executive, has said he did not learn of a device used to cheat on emissions tests until shortly before the company’s public admission.

item.title: Global Health: Zika May Increase Risk of Mental Illness, Researchers Say
item.description: Even if infants appear normal at birth, they could later have problems like autism, bipolar disorder or schizophrenia, experts fear, based on similar infections.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: A pregnant woman waits for an examination for mosquito-borne viruses like Zika at a maternity ward in Honduras. Experts say the Zika virus closely resembles some infectious agents that have been linked to autism, bipolar disorder and schizophrenia.

item.title: Turkey Blames Kurdish Militia for Ankara Attack, Challenging U.S.
item.description: In blaming a Syrian Kurdish militia supported by the United States, Turkey added urgency to a question its president asked about American support.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: The relatives of victims of a car bombing in Ankara, Turkey, mourned outside a morgue on Thursday.

item.title: Mohamed Hassanein Heikal, Prominent Egyptian Journalist, Dies at 92
item.description: Mr. Heikal’s career was defined by his close partnership with President Gamal Abdel Nasser, whom he helped write landmark speeches and a political manifesto.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Mohamed Hassanein Heikal joking with friends in 2015 at his home in Cairo, days before his 92nd birthday.
